document.masterDocTitle: On the subfamily Cypricercinae McKenzie, 1971 (Crustacea, Ostracoda) from Thailand, with the description of six new species 2379

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: On the subfamily Cypricercinae McKenzie, 1971 (Crustacea, Ostracoda) from Thailand, with the description of six new species 2379

subSubSection.paragraph:
Pseudostrandesia calapanensis ( Tressler, 1937 )
( Figs 32–34 )

1937
Strandesia calapanensis Tressler
: 197, Figs 33–35 .

1981
Strandesia uenoi Klie
— Victor & Fernando: 474.

2009
Pseudostrandesia calapanensis
— Savatenalinton & Martens: 19.
Material examined. Many females from several samples (see Table 2 ).

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2. List of localities of
Pseudostrandesia calapanensis ( Tressler, 1937 )
recorded in this study.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Carapace in lateral view elongated, greatest height situated at c. 1/3 of length, anterior margin broadly rounded, posterior margin bluntly pointed; valve surface smooth, set with dispersed small setae; carapace in dorsal view subelliptical, greatest width situated at 2/3 of its length, anterior extremity pointed, posterior extremity rounded, LV overlapping RV; LV with internal groove along valve margin; inner lamella with one inner list; RV with large marginal selvage; A1 with long Wouters organ and long Rome organ, aesthetasc ya short; aesthetasc Y on A2 long; two large bristles on third endite of Mx1 serrated; T1 without d-seta; length of distal claw of caudal ramus c. 3/8 of that of ramus, distal seta as long as proximal claw; caudal ramus attachment with Triebel’s loop situated at middle of distal part of main branch, dorsal and ventral branches well-developed.

Differential diagnosis.
Pseudostrandesia calapanensis ( Tressler, 1937 )
superficially resembles
P. phetchabunensis
sp. nov. It can be distinguished from it by the shape of the carapace in lateral and dorsal view, the presence of a large selvage on the anterior margin of the RV, the length of the shorter apical seta on the terminal segment of the A1, the morphology of the A2-exopodite and by the pair of apical setae on the penultimate segment of the T2.

Ecology. While no information on the ecology of this species was given by Tressler (1937) , Victor & Fernando (1981b) reported it from ricefields, ponds and roadside ditches. We found several specimens in eight localities ranging over lakes, man-made reservoirs, swamps, and ricefields. This species was found in a pH range of 6.79–7.20 and a temperature range of 23.4–30.8° C.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 32.
Pseudostrandesia calapanensis ( Tressler, 1937 )
, female. A. Carapace, right lateral view (O.C.3144). B. Valve surface (MSU-ZOC.065). C. Carapace, dorsal view (idem). D. Carapace, ventral view (idem). E. LV, interior view (O.C.3143). F. RV, interior view (idem). Scale bar: A, C–F: 200 µm; B: 14 µm. Arrows point toward the anterior end.

subSubSection.paragraph: Md-palp as in Fig. 33D–F , Md-coxa as in Fig. 33G .
T3 as in Fig. 34D–E .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 33.
Pseudostrandesia calapanensis ( Tressler, 1937 )
, female. A. A1 (O.C.3143). B. A2 (idem). C. A2, terminal segment (idem). D. Md-palp, showing α, β and Ύ setae (idem). E. Md-palp (idem). F. Md-palp, terminal segment (idem). G. Md-coxa (idem). Scale bar: A–B, G: 100 µm; C–F: 50 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. The original description of
S. calapanensis
, based on material from the Philippines , was brief and provided only an illustration of the carapace in lateral view, of the Mx1 and of the T2. A redescription, including more illustrations of both valves and soft parts, of this species was given by Victor & Fernando (1981b) , based on new material collected from the Philippines . We found that the morphology of valves and limbs of the Thai specimens is congruent with that of the specimens from the Philippines , except for the valves surface, which is pitted in the material from the Philippines , and smooth in the Thai specimens, and for the Ύ seta on the Md-palp (illustrated as smooth in the specimens from the Philippines , hirsute in the Thai specimens).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 34.
Pseudostrandesia calapanensis ( Tressler, 1937 )
, female. A. Mx1 (MSU-ZOC.066). B. T1 (idem). C. T2 (O.C.3143). D. T3 (MSU-ZOC.066). E. T3, apical pincer (idem). F. Caudal ramus attachment (O.C.3143). G. Caudal ramus (idem). Scale bars: A–B, E: 50 µm; C–D, F–G: 100 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph: This species is thus far recorded from the Philippines ( Tressler 1937 ; Victor & Fernando 1981b ), Taiwan
1) The dorsal margin of the valves is arched in the Nigerian specimens, but straight in specimens from the Philippines and Thailand .

2) In the Nigerian specimens, the valve surface as examined under light microscope was ornamented with polygonal reticulation and punctuate with tubercles. These features are not found in the specimens from the Philippines and Thailand .
3) The proportion between distal claw and ramus in the caudal ramus is also different. It is 1:2.8-1: 3.3 in Southeast Asian specimens, but 1:2.0 in African specimens.
